New Records: The Phillies entered the night with a 34-game winning streak when their starter pitched seven or more innings. It was the longest streak in franchise history and the second-longest streak in MLB history. The 1942 Cardinals won 42 in a row.
It was the first time in franchise history the Phillies had struck out 16-plus times in consecutive games.
Key Match Events: Aaron Nola pitched brilliantly against Milwaukee, allowing one run in seven innings, allowing only three hits and one walk and striking out nine.
Rhys Hoskins hit a solo homer to left field in the fifth inning.
The Phillies struck out 16 times on Wednesday.
Post-Match Reflections: Phillies manager Rob Thomson emphasized the need to get back to their two-strike approach, use the field, and eliminate chase.
Alec Bohm reflected on the team's strikeouts, acknowledging the need to put the ball in play more but also recognizing the quality of the opposing pitching.
Alec Bohm expressed confidence in the team's ability to avoid similar struggles as last fall in the NLCS.
Rob Thomson expressed confidence in the Phillies' lineup against any team.
